title: 111_s90
content: The Act is titled the "Government Neutrality in Contracting Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Government Neutrality in Contracting Act" aims to promote open competition, maintain neutrality in labor relations, reduce construction costs, expand job opportunities, and prevent discrimination on Federal construction projects. SEC. 3. PRESERVATION OF OPEN COMPETITION AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENT NEUTRALITY. The head of each executive agency must ensure that bid specifications and project agreements do not restrict agreements with labor organizations or discriminate against bidders. The provisions of this section prohibit bidders, offerors, contractors, or subcontractors from becoming a signatory to a labor organization agreement or refusing to adhere to such an agreement for a construction project. This prohibition does not apply to contracts awarded before the enactment of this Act. The Act prohibits contractors and subcontractors from being bound by labor organization agreements for construction projects, regardless of subcontract dates. Recipients of grants and financial assistance must ensure project documents do not include these requirements. The Act prohibits contractors and subcontractors from being bound by labor organization agreements for construction projects. Failure to comply with this requirement may result in actions taken by the executive agency awarding the contract or grant. The head of an executive agency may exempt a project from certain requirements if special circumstances exist to avert a threat to public health, safety, or national security. Special circumstances cannot be based on labor disputes with nonsignatory contractors. The head of an executive agency can exempt a project from specific requirements if there are special circumstances to prevent a threat to public health, safety, or national security. This exemption cannot be based on labor disputes with contractors who are not signatories to labor organizations. Additionally, certain projects can be exempted from subsections (a) or (c) provisions if approved by the agency head. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council must amend federal contracts within 60 days of this Act's enactment if they contain specific requirements or prohibitions. This applies to projects with bid specifications, project agreements, or construction contracts awarded before the Act's enactment. The Regulatory Council will amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to implement the provisions of this section, defining terms like construction contract, executive agency, and labor organization.
